awd_titl_txt: Block Copolymer Based Porous Nanostructures from Non-Equilibrium Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project is on advanced porous nanostructures made from specialized plastic materials ("block copolymers") using novel non-equilibrium processes.  It will promote scientific understanding of the fundamental principles of how to controllably push polymer-based materials systems away from equilibrium towards the successful generation of porous asymmetric membranes or highly ordered ("single-crystal") nanostructures. The project may offer profound impact in a range of technologically important areas. For example, if successful, the project will provide advanced membrane materials for applications in high-resolution biopharmaceutical separations and will allow use of porous polymer molds to structure higher-melting materials like metals or semiconductors into periodically ordered porous single-crystal nanostructures of interest in the microelectronic industry. Besides expected benefits for society in a number of areas of technology development, the project will also support education and diversity by promoting interest of a diverse range of students in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project aims to investigate the synthesis and preparation, characterization, and formation mechanisms of porous block copolymer directed nanostructures obtained using non-equilibrium formation processes. Two distinct approaches will be pursued employing ABC triblock terpolymer self-assembly: One submits the terpolymers to non-solvent induced phase separation enabling asymmetric membrane formation, the other to transient laser heating to access temperature processing regimes hitherto unexplored for polymers. The aim of the proposed program is to understand the underlying fundamental chemical, physical and kinetic formation principles enabling generalization of results to other classes of materials. The proposed research includes synthesis of all components, preparation of porous nanostructured materials using the two non-equilibrium formation principles, and characterization of the final assembly structures using various scattering and electron microscopy techniques. Interdisciplinarity will be a central feature of the effort. The program will further involve training and development of human resources, including the participation of underrepresented groups, and industrial outreach.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this single investigator program on ‘block copolymer based porous nanostructures from non-equilibrium processes’ was to build fundamental understanding around the effects of driving a particular class of spontaneously self-organizing (self-assembly, SA) macromolecules with blocked chain architectures (i.e., block copolymers, BCPs) and their SA directed composite materials away from equilibrium on their structure, order, and dynamics. This was achieved by investigating porous BCP directed nanostructures obtained using two separate non-equilibrium formation processes, i.e., formation processes during which the polymer system cannot reach thermodynamic equilibrium. The first was submitting BCPs to non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS), a process employed since the 1960’s for the formation of asymmetric ultrafiltration (UF) membranes. The second approach used transient laser heating, a hitherto unexplored process borrowed from the microelectronic industry, to access high temperature processing regimes of BCP SA directed thin films beyond their thermal stability limit. 

Representative highlights of this work in terms of intellectual merit can be summarized by three specific lines of research. A first series of studies on the use of NIPS to generate BCP SA directed inorganic materials included carbons (Macromolecules 2021), oxides, and nitrides (Macromolecular Chemistry and Physics 2023). Carefully investigating effects of different experimental parameters, because of the non-equilibrium nature of the formation process, resulting materials exhibited a combination of asymmetric pore structure along the film normal and mesopores (pores of sizes between 2 nm and 50 nm) everywhere. This combination of structural pore volume characteristics was shown to be advantageous, by an order of magnitude increase in specific power over existing best-performing materials, when applied to electrical double layer capacitors (ACS Nano 2020). These very encouraging results suggested, following examples in nature including our lungs, that such novel film architectures combining efficient mass transport (via asymmetric porous structures) with large and easily accessible surface area (via mesopores throughout the structures) may be advantageous in a number of energy and environmental processes including energy conversion and storage as well as catalysis.

In a second set of studies transient laser heating was employed to convert BCP SA directed mesoporous nanostructures into crystalline silicon nanostructures (ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces 2018, ACS Nano 2020). Surprisingly, these results demonstrated that by using nanosecond laser pulse-induced silicon melts, porous organic polymeric network structures could act as templates for liquid silicon (melting temperature around 1400 degrees Celsius). This was possible as the fast melting and conformal liquid backfilling processes essentially beat the kinetics of oxidative polymer degradation processes. Furthermore, following an earlier theoretical study on requirements to achieve topologically protected quantum materials (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 2018), this work further demonstrated that the resulting films had the required symmetry properties consistent with formation of so-called Weyl-points in topological quantum materials (i.e., lack of an inversion center and deformation along the film normal via thin film processing). Along a similar vein, in a final set of investigations the group identified BCP SA directed pathways to superconductors with properties not only determined by their atomic lattices, but also by the BCP SA directed mesostructure (Advanced Materials 2021). Such quantum metamaterials pave the way to a novel class of soft matter (polymer) enabled quantum materials, with significant academic as well as technological promise (Advanced Materials2022).

In terms of broader impacts this research program created an unusually cross-disciplinary educational environment for students. They conducted research reaching from organic polymer and inorganic materials synthesis across in-depth materials structure and property characterizations all the way to superconductivity, i.e., areas that typically have little to no overlap because of their respective orthogonal educational background. Students worked on state-of-the-art equipment in Cornell’s research facilities including x-ray scattering set-ups at Cornell’s High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) funded by NSF (and other organizations) as well as other materials characterization facilities including electron microscopy facilities of the Cornell Center for Materials Research (CCMR). Finally, students wrote publications and presented their work at meetings and conferences. The five-year program (three years of base funding and two years funded via a NSF Creativity Award) was highly productive, resulting in 29 publications in peer-reviewed journals (~6 per year), including 4 in ACS Nano (IF = 17.1), 2 in Advanced Functional Materials (IF = 19), 4 in Advanced Materials (impact factor, IF = 29.4), 1 in Advanced Optical Materials (IF = 10.1), 2 in Chemistry of Materials (IF = 8.6), 1 in Energy and Environmental Science (IF = 39.7), 3 in Macromolecules (IF = 5.5), and 1 in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (IF = 11.1). Finally, the program supported multifaceted outreach with activities ranging from generating support pathways for students in the STEM fields, working with educators to generate new and engaging teaching content, using BCP SA based art to engage with the public, and working with various start-up companies to translate research results into innovations.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2023
Modified by: Ulrich B Wiesner

The five-year program (three years of base funding and two years funded via a NSF Creativity Award) was highly productive, resulting in 29 publications in peer-reviewed journals (~6 per year), including 4 inACS Nano(IF = 17.1), 2 inAdvanced Functional Materials(IF = 19), 4 inAdvanced Materials(impact factor, IF = 29.4), 1 inAdvanced Optical Materials(IF = 10.1), 2 inChemistry of Materials(IF = 8.6), 1 inEnergy and Environmental Science(IF = 39.7),3 inMacromolecules(IF = 5.5), and 1 inProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences(IF = 11.1).
